awd_titl_txt: Dimensions: Collaborative Research: Time after Time: Adaptive Seasonal Timing Drives the Sequential Origin of Community Biodiversity
awd_abstract_narration:
The timing of seasonal life cycles is a critical question underlying many biological processes, including the generation and maintenance of biodiversity and agriculture production and food security.  Animals and plants must synchronize their lives with the seasons to avoid freezing or overheating and to exploit seasonal resources. The goal of this grant is to understand how historic and contemporary shifts in seasonality can facilitate biological diversification in insect communities. In the short term, such shifts have caused rapid evolution of new crop pests and associated parasite communities. The proposed research tests 1) whether the same processes explain more ancient diversification of communities, and 2) whether changing climates will disrupt or promote diversification in the future. The results may inform many scientific fields, from basic research on the genesis of new species to applied control of agricultural pests. This project includes workshops with high school teachers and students to build curricula supporting "learning by doing" and meeting national standards, as well as providing training for graduate students and postdocs. 

This project includes genomic analysis of dipteran pest insects, including the apple fly Rhagoletis pomonella and blueberry maggot fly Rhagoletis mendax plus the community of parasitoid wasps that attack these flies. Genomic work will integrate with 1) functional studies of the overwintering hibernation of both the flies and the wasps from hormonal and molecular perspectives, and 2) computational simulations of the responses of the flies and their parasites to projected seasonal shifts resulting from climate change.

por.por_cntn:
From the perspective of the Intellectual Merit of our award, we had several major outcomes. It is well known that evolution in the components of dormancy phases in the lifecycles of plants, animals, and microbes can facilitate diversification, range expansion, and persistence of populations in the face of climate change. The overarching theme of our award was to understand the extent to which the genetic, developmental, and physiological architectures of dormancy timing may facilitate or constrain adaptation. First, we have shown that the pre-winter and post-winter portions of the apple maggot fly lifecycle are not constrained genetically, giving them greater potential for adaptation in the face of climate change and future range expansion. Second, we have identified reactive oxygen species, free radicals of oxygen, as critical signaling molecules that regulate how deep in dormancy insects may be. Insects that are not as deep in dormancy are more likely to react to their environments, thus non-reactiveness is a buffer against inappropriate expressions of dormancy that could limit organismal adaptation to climate change. Third, our data help to support an emerging hypothesis that we need to stop thinking about dormancy as a complete pause or arrest of organismal lifecycles, but instead we need to consider dormancy to be a tightly regulated form of slow development. This perspective changes how practitioners in the field will hunt for the mechanistic genetic and physiological mechanisms underlying evolution of dormancy and thus persistence of population under future anthropogenic change. 

 

From the perspective of the Broader Impacts of our award we have also had several major outcomes. First, this grant award had major outcomes in human resource development. We trained 4 postdoctoral scholars, each of which are now gainfully employed in science careers. We trained 4 graduate students, each of which is coming to the successful end of their PhD educations and each of which are poised for careers in STEM. Last, we have directly trained 9 undergraduate students, each of which has had a tailored mentoring experience in the sciences. Second, we have had substantial outcomes in teaching and educational experiences. One of the outstanding problems is a lack of understanding among the public as to how evolution by natural selection works. They often confuse the concept of “survival of the fittest” with physical fitness and generally lack a working understanding of the role of natural genetic variation in evolution. We have developed a curriculum designed to fill this gap in understanding in high-school biology classrooms based directly on needs, opportunities, and constraints communicated to us by working high school teachers. We have intensively trained 2 focal high-school teachers in developing curricula in genetics and evolution targets specifically to the high school classroom. Beyond our focal teachers, we have trained another 24 high school teachers in using our curriculum and we have data that we have reached at least 418 high school students directly with our hands-on immersive curriculum in genetics and evolution.
